I built my own omni assistant using Gemini 1.5 Flash to guide me through Super Mario 64.   Gemini can see what I do on my screen and communicate with me in real time via voice, and thanks to the long 1M context, it has a memory of everything we do together.   Incredible.

Updated Gemini 1.5 Pro report: MATH benchmark for specialized version now at 91.1%, SOTA 3 years ago was 6.9%, overall a lot of progress from February to May in all benchmarks

For a long time, we‚Äôve been working towards a universal AI agent that can be truly helpful in everyday life. Today at #GoogleIO we showed off our latest progress towards this: Project Astra. Here‚Äôs a video of our prototype, captured in real time.

Making great progress on the Gemini Era. We think of @GoogleDeepMind as the engine room of @Google in the AI era. Thrilled to share our vision at #GoogleIO incl the latest Gemini model 1.5 Flash, Project Astra our universal AI agent effort, our new gen video model Veo, Imagen 3 & lots more!  https://deepmind.google/
Super excited for my first #GoogleIO tomorrow and to share what we've been working on!

AlphaFold3 is insane. MutS protein (green) recognizes base mismatches in DNA (gray), after which it slides off to find MutL matchmaker protein (blue), which positions and activates MutH nuclease (pink) to nick a hemimethylated GATC sequence (red) to activate removal and repair of‚Ä¶

Announcing AlphaFold 3: our state-of-the-art AI model for predicting the structure and interactions of all life‚Äôs molecules. üß¨  Here‚Äôs how we built it with @IsomorphicLabs and what it means for biology. üßµ https://dpmd.ai/3URDiNo

Thrilled to announce AlphaFold 3 which can predict the structures and interactions of nearly all of life‚Äôs molecules with state-of-the-art accuracy including proteins, DNA and RNA. Biology is a complex dynamical system so modeling interactions is crucial https://blog.google/technology/ai/google-deepmind-isomorphic-alphafold-3-ai-model

Thanks to AI, new medical breakthroughs may one day move from years to mere months.  Listen to @GoogleDeepMind CEO @DemisHassabis‚Äô full conversation with @TEDChris on how this tech is helping us solve some of science‚Äôs biggest mysteries: t.ted.com/sRLw3lQ

My first time on the @TEDTalks stage was a really fun experience. @TEDchris and I had a great conversation about the ways AI will accelerate scientific discovery and help us solve the biggest problems facing humanity, from tackling cancer to climate: https://www.ted.com/talks/demis_hassabis_how_ai_is_unlocking_the_secrets_of_nature_and_the_universe

Very sad to hear of Dan Dennett's passing, I remember with great fondness the wonderful far-ranging conversation we had on AI, creativity, qualia, and of course consciousness, including Theseus's ship as regards to AI. He was a great thinker, and will be much missed.

New research from @GoogleDeepMind brings together soccer and robotics. Using reinforcement learning, robots display agile and reactive movements similar to a soccer player, no shin guards needed:) https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/scirobotics.adi8022

I hope this is not another honeymoon thing but the gemini pro 1.5-preview is like..crazy good right nowüßê?  Just tried it, asked for complete code, actually takes over 8 minutes to generate complete code as I asked.  It follows the system prompt WELL. This feels better than Opus.

Delighted and honoured to receive a Knighthood for services to AI. It‚Äôs been an incredible journey so far building @GoogleDeepMind over the past 15 years, helping accelerate the field and grow the UK & global AI ecosystems. Thanks to everyone who helped make this dream possible!

If you want a hint about the future of AI, it is worth trying Gemini 1.5 with the 1M token context window, now available to everyone, apparently.  Some of my experiments: giving it a video and having it figure out a recipe, execute instructions, watching my screen, summarize work

We are rolling out Gemini 1.5 Pro API so that you can keep building amazing stuff on top of the model like we've seen in the past few weeks.  Also, if you just want to play with Gemini 1.5, we removed the waitlist: aistudio.google.com  Last, but not least, we pushed the model‚Ä¶

We're starting to roll out API support for Gemini 1.5 Pro for developers.  We're excited to see what you build with the 1M token context window!  We'll be onboarding people to the API slowly at first, and then we'll ramp it up. In the meantime, developers can try out Gemini 1.5‚Ä¶
Excited to deepen our partnership with NVIDIA and bring the breakthrough capabilities of the Blackwell GPU to our teams and Cloud customers.

TacticAI is an AI system that can advise football coaches on tactics & plays https://deepmind.google/discover/blog/tacticai-ai-assistant-for-football-tactics/ This was a really fun project to work on in collaboration with my much loved Liverpool FC @LFC - fingers crossed we win the league this year to give Klopp a fitting send off!

Excited to announce SIMA, a general AI agent for games & 3D virtual settings. It marks the first time an agent has demonstrated it can follow natural-language instructions to carry out a wide range of tasks across a large array of game worlds, similar to how a human would play.

I am really excited to reveal what @GoogleDeepMind's  Open Endedness Team has been up to üöÄ. We introduce Genie üßû, a foundation world model trained exclusively from Internet videos that can generate an endless variety of action-controllable 2D worlds given image prompts.

We have a long history of supporting responsible open source & science, which can drive rapid research progress, so we‚Äôre proud to release Gemma: a set of lightweight open models, best-in-class for their size, inspired by the same tech used for Gemini https://blog.google/technology/developers/gemma-open-models/

A hard test of Gemini 1.5 that every other AI has failed. I gave it a truly over-the-top RPG (the 352 page rulebook for 60 Years in Space) and asked it to role up a character  The instructions are scattered across many pages, and are very complicated, but Gemini seemed to get it.
Gemini 1.5 Pro's 1,000,000+ token context length is incredible.  I got early access and spent my Saturday night running tests.  Here are 6 impressive capabilities I found:

Been testing Gemini 1.5 pro and i'm really impressed so far  Recall has been outstanding, and its really good at following instructions even with > 200k tokens.  oh and agents just got a lot better. the only missing piece is really latency + cost

To show what‚Äôs possible with the drastically huge context window in Gemini 1.5 Pro, we prompted it with the three.js examples code - over 100,000 lines of code/800k+ tokens!  (That‚Äôs not even the max, it can handle millions of tokens üòÄ)  Gemini was able to process all the code‚Ä¶

What the fuck...  On a benchmark measuring precision recall from a FULL DAY OF AUDIO, Gemini Pro 1.5, when just seeing the *audio file* directly (no transcription!) far outperforms GPT-4 with a Whisper transcription.  This is mind-bending.

Here‚Äôs a fun demo of long-context understanding. First, we asked the model to find 3 amusing moments in the 402-page pdf transcription of the iconic Apollo 11 mission. Then we uploaded a simple drawing of a boot and it identified the moment we had in mind: Neil‚Äôs one small step!

AGI skeptics love using totally bizarre definitions of AGI to argue their case. For a sensible definition, consider the Competent AGI level from the Levels of AGI paper by @merrierm et. al.  https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.02462  Next time you see a silly definition, point to this paper.

Here's a great example of human-AI collaboration to obtain new results in mathematics. In this case, a team from DeepMind has used LLMs to obtain the best known lower bound for the cap-set problem. Of course, there's more to it than talking to ChatGPT.   https://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/dec/14/ai-scientists-make-exciting-discovery-using-chatbots-to-solve-maths-problems

Excited for our latest breakthrough published in @Nature today, #FunSearch ('searching' in 'function' space) is the first system to make new verifiable discoveries in open problems in math & CS, we applied it to find a more efficient solution to the classic 'bin packing' problem
